summary: Jack Torrance (Jack Nicholson) becomes winter caretaker at the isolated Overlook Hotel in Colorado, hoping to cure his writer's block. He settles in along with his wife, Wendy (Shelley Duvall), and his son, Danny (Danny Lloyd), who is plagued by psychic premonitions. As Jack's writing goes nowhere and Danny's visions become more disturbing, Jack discovers the hotel's dark secrets and begins to unravel into a homicidal maniac hell-bent on terrorizing his family.

Incredible film by Stanley Kubrick. I don't watch movies often, but this surely was one to remember. It is different from the common horror film in it's slower progression, which i'm sure many didn't like, but the progression, atmosphere, and camerawork of this movie make it truly unique. It's take on horror is more gradual, deep, and connected, with actors who were purposefully chosen due to their "imperfect/ugly" appearances. Overall though, The Shining is a good movie for if you want a movie which is LESS like the original book with it's unique plot, and more of a different story with different characters overall. The movie also promotes many theories and leads to speculation, which if you don't look up the answers to them, can be a difficult challenge to try to answer yourself.

Definitely a good movie to watch with friends, and a great beginner horror-fan movie as well.

A Horror Classic. The acting is phenomenal with perfect casting and real unease and tension amongst everyone that builds throughout. Jack Torrance is one of the best villains in any film with a beyond memorable performance that lingers well after the credits role. This film easily is not as iconic and memorable without Jack Nicholson being cast. Wendy & Danny are excellent also. The cinematography is phenomenal in making a bland location extremely memorable with amazing well framed and lit shots with terrific camerawork throughout. The music is incredibly creepy, memorable and varied which is a tremendous accomplishment as well. The pacing is flawless with the tension not just coming from the creepiness, music tone changes and surreal images but really the tension amongst Jack and the others as they slowly crack. The climax of the door axing is incredibly terrifying. The only problem is the editing and the abstractness that runs throughout this film from the middle to the end. While they are incredibly well done scenes on their own being very creepy and unsettling, they don't form or take away from the narrative at times. Perfect examples are scenes like Room 237, Mr. Grady, Wendy and the two guests in the room at the end, The Shining subplot, Redrum meaning, etc. I feel the ending shot should've been the only abstract scene left in similar to the open ending to The Thing (1982) and focused squarely on Jack going insane and leaving things sparsely open to interpretation as to why. This would've let the viewer fill in the gaps and because this is so well done it would've been easy for them to pain a picture far more terrifying than abstract. Key scenes like Jack at the bar and him writing should be left in to leave enough breadcrumbs for a viewer to form their own opinion but it definitely needed to tone down on the weird abstract scenes. It left me more scratching my head afterwards than terrified. Though it did that very well throughout as well. Anyone who is a Kubrick fan, a fan of any actors in this, or Horror films in general will love this.

This movie has historically been criticized for not being "too scary" but that doesn't necessarily have to be a bad thing. It is still a peculiar thriller, and with the exception of a few fictitious elements, it could've counted as realistic. This is the problem; the decision was not clear on whether to take the fiction into consideration while writing the plot, or just use it as an appendage to an already-consistent plot, which resulted in a bit of hollowness. However, with taking the aforementioned into consideration or without it, Stanley Kubrick's pure artistry in filming should make The Shining a must-watch.

The movie I will be reviewing is The Shining, directed by Stanley Kubrick.  The genre of this movie is horror, thriller, and psychological.  I love horror movies, and I have seen this a few times.  I enjoyed The Shining because it makes you think about what you're watching and keeps you on your toes.  The movie is based on the book from Stephen King.  
	The main characters, Jack, Wendy, and their son, Danny go to an abandoned Overlook Hotel in colorado.  Jack is a writer and goes there to cure his writer's block.  Danny has visions and they start getting worse the longer that they are at the hotel.  Jack starts discovering the hotel's dark secrets and goes into a manic state, causing him to terrorize his family.  
	I like this film because of the horror and psychological sense of it.  I like the chilling feel that I get from the ghosts appearing in the hotel.  The uneasy music in the background adds to the eerie feeling.  The acting in this movie is unreal.  They really capture the characters from the novel.  The emotions that the actors provide are amazing.  The clothing is fitting for the time period and suits the theme.  For example, Danny has a spaceship on his shirt, and they show him playing with toys to provide the innocence of a child.  The movie really captures how a normal family can switch instantly.  
	The theme that I got from The Shining is fearing paranormal activity and isolation.  The themes showed me how paranormal activity can be very sinister.  The isolation theme showed me how much isolation can cause a manic state.  It shows how being alone can cause you to do things that you never thought of doing.  I think others can learn how isolation and paranormal activity can cause mania, and others can see what it's like for people to switch like Jack does.  
	If you love psychological and horror movies, The Shining is a great movie to watch.  I would recommend this movie to horror movie lovers.  I wouldn't recommend this movie to people who feel uncomfortable with seeing mental illness decline, and people who get spooked easily because it could cause a ton of uneasiness.  Overall, The Shining is a great film to watch if you love horror and psychological movies.

The Shining is a horror film directed by Stanley Kubrick based on the novel of the same name by Stephen King. It tells the story of Jack Torrance, a struggling writer and recovering alcoholic who becomes the winter caretaker at the Overlook Hotel in the Rocky Mountains, accompanied by his wife Wendy and young son Danny. As they become isolated in the hotel during a snowstorm, Jack becomes increasingly erratic and violent, while Danny exhibits psychic abilities and begins to experience disturbing visions. The film explores themes of domestic abuse, failed fatherhood, and the impact of trauma on a family. It is known for its immersive cinematography, using the Steadicam to create a sense of momentum and disorientation, and its use of musical scores by György Ligeti and Krzysztof Penderecki to enhance the atmosphere of unease. The film has become a classic of the horror genre and has been analyzed for its various themes and symbols.

A modern masterpiece.  Rightfully called one of the scariest movies of all time.  This is the undisputed paragon of haunted house epics. The Shining is essentially Stephen King's reboot of Shirley Jackson's 1959 haunted house epic The Haunting of Hill House; also about an evil supernaturally possessed house that draws people into it; a house with a sordid dark history and many deaths; with the purpose of absorbing people into it's lair; thereby absorbing their powers.  In both stories the inhabitants of the house have ESP; which is why the house has chosen them; and why it is trying to destroy and absorb them into it's interdimensional vortex.  The book is also inspired by Stephen King's experiences staying at the infamous Stanley Hotel in Estes Park Colorado; nestled in the heart of the Rocky Mountains.  He and his wife Tabitha stayed there in 1974 for one night; staying in the infamous room 217; and he was instantly transfixed and brainstormed the Shining story based on his real life creepy experiences there.  In addition the book is an allegory about King's own substance abuse; which was careening out of control in the late 70s; the story itself being a projection about his own fears about his illness, and the effects it could have on his wife and two small children.  So from all that we get The Shining.  The story is about the Torrance family;  Jack, Wendy and Danny;  and how they move into the Overlook hotel; a Colorado ski resort in the Rockies where several murders and mysterious deaths have occurred in the past.  Eventually it becomes clear the house is possessed and very much alive; and is attempting to manipulate Jack to kill Wendy and Danny; so that it can absorb Danny's considerable ESP powers.  The movie follows Jack's Exorcist-like deterioration from a mild mannered freelance writer to a demonic psychopath; who is being helped in his nefarious plot by the spirits in the house.  The grand sweep of Kubrick's direction is absolutely stunning; rare for a horror film to have such virtuosity behind the camera.  Kubrick infact helped invent and develop steadicam technology for this movie which continues to have an impact on film today.  King famously hated this movie; which makes sense; he is a fundamentally different artist than Kubrick.  Kubrick was an absurdist; and King is a romantic, (of the Edgar Allen Poe type).  And admittedly the movie isn't very faithful to the book.  But Kubrick's downcast scorched earth perspective; dissecting the characters from a microscope like a merciless scientist dissecting a squirming bug under glass; absolutely adds to the drama.  So much of the movie's effectiveness is just that devastating; psychotic mood; tension filled and terrifying; tension so thick you can cut it like a knife; which fills the screen as soon as the movie starts.  No one could have accomplished this dazzling, transfixing and terrifying mood better than Stanley Kubrick.  Inspite of King's misgivings about him; Kubrick was actually born to direct this movie. And there are so many stunning horror set pieces here.  The British Grady twins chanting in perfect, eerie unison; Danny big-wheeling across the miles of hardwood resort floors like he's in the Indiana 500; seeing horrific phantasmagoria all around him; Wendy stumbling upon the spirit of Horace Derwent and his bear-suited employee in compromising positions; and on and on; so many terrifying, effective scenes.  The movie is pitch perfect; there is not an off-key scene in the entire opus; they are all masterful and all work beautifully.  Easily one of the best movies ever made!  Highly recommend!

Other than Andrei Tarkovsky and perhaps and handful of others, it's hard to imagine a director with more visual awareness than Stanley Kubrick.  While not his best film, The Shining is filled with unforgettable imagery – beautifully composed shots, remarkable camera movement, perfectly blocked scenes.  Set in the snowy mountains of Colorado, Jack Torrance (Jack Nicholson), teacher and writer, accepts an assignment as a winter caretaker at a remote luxury hotel with a macabre history.  With wife (Shelley Duvall) and son (Danny Lloyd) in tow, things soon begin to spiral out of control.  On top of the visuals, the acting is top-notch and the score is appropriately eerie.  Does it drag at times?  Certainly.  Is it for all tastes?  No.  But even in the dull moments, it is beautiful to look at.

Very loosely based on the book, which is very chilling and shocking, this is a great film. Having seen The Shawshank Redemption, Stand By Me and It and liking all three of them, I knew I should check out the Shining. I did feel that Jack Torrence's hallucinations, apparitions and time-warps were introduced a little too quickly and the build up to the ending was rushed too. But it is very stylishly filmed, making perfect use of an amazing set built at Elstree and a gliding Steadicam, and the music is atmospheric. The story is also effective, and there are really nice touches in the script. Kubrick here tries to be different, and I think he does a superb job at it. The Shining is more chilling rather than shocking, the blood flowing from the doors and the old woman in the bathtub made my hairs stand up on the back of my neck, and is constantly discomforting in an eerie sort of way. Jack Nicolson gives a barnstorming performance as Jack, a performance that is both hammy and disturbing, and Shelley Duvall does decently in a somewhat thankless role. Young Danny Lloyd is superb as Danny, his chanting of Redrum especially became increasingly hypnotic and distorted. The film concludes with a fairly suspenseful ending, and is overall a film with one or two problems and a very loose adaptation but it is a chilling adaptation with Kubrick succeeding at being different. 9/10 Bethany Cox

One of the most overrated movies of all time. A beneficiary of the undeserved "mad genius" status of Kubrick which is really just a sort of pretentious nihilism exacerbated by OCD. 
This is one of those movies that tricks normal people into thinking it was any good at all by it's many nonsensical and pointless plot threads that are never explained and never go anywhere. You're meant to believe it's all so very deep and artistic, but in reality, it's just poor and lazy writing. There are so many Chekhov's guns in this movie, I lost count. 

As Solzhenitsyn once wrote, "It's all so arty, there's no art left in it."

I don't think this is the scariest film ever made, but it's certainly well-made by Stanley Kubrick, a master of his craft. Jack Nicholson's unhinged performance is captivating. Shelley Duvall's character simpers and flaps around the place in a rather boneless manner, which is a little annoying, on the other hand. The Shining is a strange one. In many respects it's an excellent film in its own right, but it's a terrible adaptation, with Stephen King famously saying he hated it. Many changes, large and small, are apparent that ride roughshod over King's novel - but still have strengths of their own. As an exercise in film-making and as a film with buckets full of suspense, it is an undoubted success, but it isn't flawless.

This is a very atmospheric and distinctly chilling film, with an unsettling and somewhat claustrophobic feel to it throughout. There are numerous hints about what's to come from quite early on and it has a somewhat slow plot but I'd say that works in its favour, for this film certainly as it leaves the viewer trying to second guess when things may suddenly 'come to a head', as it were.

Its certainly not an utter gorefest throughout, as horror films go but as you may have guessed, it is very tense at times and I really liked the way the wide-angle camera (pan) shots and the music (quite old fashioned, spooky music certainly, often featuring strings (stringed instruments - it has a Hitchcockian feel to it)) go well together. The cast does a good job, certainly Jack Nicholson as John Torrance and Shelley Duvall as his wife, Wendy. I can understand why this is regarded as a classic horror film, with both of their performances being quite memorable. Wendy's look of sheer terror when things come to a head is quite chilling and certainly memorable, as is Jack's when he embarks on the infamous rampage.

If your a fan of horror films and the like, then I'd definitely recommend this film.

The opening of "The Shining" says it all: a vast landscape that is majestic and yet ominously forbidding; a desperately isolated car winding its way ever deeper into the madness of the terrain. As the film progresses, we are drawn ever more fully into a disorienting labyrinth of primordial evil, cabin fever, and mysteriously intertwined fates until a consuming terror is evoked which is characteristic of Kubrick's perfectly calibrated kaleidoscope of unholy lunacy and suffocating claustrophobia. In true Kubrick fashion, we are left with the sense of an evil that we cannot name, born equally of the tenuous limitations of our own sanity and the fabric of a sinister spirit world lurking beneath the everyday surface. Although departing considerably from Stephen King's own vision of the material, "The Shining" is a terrifying, hallucinogenic experience that befits the best of the horror genre.

The Shining is one of the most classic horror films, and for good reason. It is a movie which truly defined the genre of psychological horror, using atmosphere and symbolism throughout to thoroughly unsettle its audience. It follows Jack Torrance, a struggling writer, and his family as they spend the winter as the caretakers of a large, empty hotel. However, when Jack's son, Danny, starts having psychic visions of terrifying murders and ghosts that haunt the hotel, it quickly becomes apparent that there is something very wrong. 

I feel that what makes The Shining such an effective psychological thriller is the extensive use of mise-en-scene to create the atmosphere. For example, the hotel layout as shown in the movie is impossible- the rooms and hallways twist and turn to make a space that is much larger than the physical hotel. This creates uncertainty, and unsettles the audience. In the famous scene where the child, Danny, rides around on his tricycle, the camera glides low and close behind him as he pedals through the halls. We don't know what lies beyond each corner- we see what Danny sees, when he sees it. The suspense is masterfully constructed, and we have no choice but to watch in fear as Jack spirals down into madness. 

However, where it excels at being extremely unsettling at points, The Shining isn't necessarily a scary movie. In fact, I would argue that all of the actual "horror" parts of the movie fell flat. For all of the build-up to the part where Jack finally snaps, the actual reveal and everything after was a complete letdown. Earlier on in the movie, Jack sustained an injury which gave him a pronounced limp- but so pronounced that any character who could break into a light jog could easily outrun him. This effectively got rid of any sense of urgency and fear, and turned something that should have been the terrifying final chase into a tedious run-around. On top of the already poor pacing, the use of plastic, Spirit- Halloween reminiscent skeletons and cobwebs added a layer of absurdity, sharply contrasting with the artful use of props throughout the rest of the film. It's almost as if the last 20 minutes had a different director altogether, which ended the movie on a rather disappointing note. 

In summary, if you're looking for a straightforward horror movie with jump scares and gross-out terror, The Shining is definitely not your movie. That being said, this movie does contain some truly brilliant, unsettling scenes. As a long-time horror movie fan, it was interesting and fun to have a horror experience that is so different from the typical ghost/demon/monster fare. Despite its faults, The Shining has an atmosphere to it that makes it such a classic horror film- and one well worth the watch.

The Shining is a cult, psychological horror film starring Jack Nicholson. In the film, struggling writer Jack Torrance agrees to be the winter caretaker of a hotel where a murder had taken place some years ago. During his stay with his wife and his son, Danny, Jack begins to feel a sinister atmosphere. Danny starts to have a series of disturbing visions and Jack's writer's block worsens. As a result, Jack goes on a murderous rampage, targeting his family. To start, the film is excessively long. If Kubrick and his editor had taken a "less is more approach" and cut the runtime to about 100 minutes, the story's pacing would better suit the tiny cast and limited settings.
With that being said, Kubrick was a master of horror and suspense in his day, and this acclaimed classic proves that he deserved his rank. The composers of this film also did some immaculate work, providing the world of cinema with one of the greatest soundtrack themes in history. The film also boasted several displays of stunning cinematography during scenes like the one filmed in the never-ending hedge maze. And though compact, the whole cast gave huge performances. Then rookie child actor, Danny Lloyd, specifically delivered a great performance despite the long hours and extensive takes. You've gotta hand it to the little dude... I enjoyed this classic; but unlike most of the film's cult following, I appreciated the film more so for its superb technical aspects rather than its adjudged, iconic creepy twins or Jack Torrance's mental breakdown one-liners. That isn't to take away from these elements of the film, though. These elements made The Shining legendary, but the entire pre- and post-production team deserve their accolades, too. In conclusion, you should see the film at least once in your lifetime. Try to avoid the hype until you have, though... 82%!
